description:
Neoarthrinium moseri is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Austria and was subsequently described as a new species in 2019.

Neoarthrinium moseri is a filamentous, anamorphic fungus, meaning it reproduces asexually through the formation of spores called conidia. The fungus produces dark-colored, septate hyphae (branching filaments) and produces brown to black, rough-walled conidia. These conidia are typically ellipsoidal or irregular in shape and are produced in clusters or chains.

Phylogenetic analysis based on DNA sequence data has placed Neoarthrinium moseri within the order Pleosporales, which is a diverse group of ascomycete fungi commonly found in soil and plant materials. The specific ecological role and significance of N. moseri in its natural environment are not yet fully understood, but it is likely involved in decomposition or other soil-based processes.
